comments:
Example output from "Console":

@@@@

java.util.MissingResourceException: Can't find resource for bundle 
java.util.PropertyResourceBundle, key icon_path
	at java.util.ResourceBundle.getObject(ResourceBundle.java:382)
	at java.util.ResourceBundle.getString(ResourceBundle.java:354)

@@@@@

It would be nice to be able to click on "java.util.ResourceBundle.getObject
(ResourceBundle.java:382)" or just "ResourceBundle.java:382" to open that type 
to the specific line (same with "ResourceBundle.java:354")-- could be indicated 
by a hyperlink.

Right now one has to:
select "ResourceBundle" and click on "Open Type" from "Console"'s pop-up menu, 
go to the opened file and use its' pop-up menu "Go to line..." (or use keyboard 
shortcut), but it would be much more convenient to be able to do it with just 
one click.

As a "temporary fix": If one would select "ResourceBundle.java:382" JDT should 
be able to parse the number after the colon, i.e. "382", and automatically run 
the "Go to line..."-action after the "Open Type"-action ...

Sebastian Davids

The OpenOnType action in the console has always worked in two ways.  If there 
is a selection in the console, only the selection is parsed.  If there is no 
selection, the entire line where the caret is currently located is parsed.  In 
both cases, if a line number is present, this is parsed so that when the editor 
is opened, the specified line is revealed and selected.  Thus the quick way to 
use this action is to simply click on the line of interest in the console, then 
right click to "Open on Type".

Verified.

One additional note: a recent enhancement to this action has now made things a 
little easier still.  You can now double click on a line in the console to 
perform the "Open on Type" action instead of single clicking on it, then right-
clicking to "Open on Type".

Well checked it out myself ... it worked.

But ... I think it should be documented somewhere and there should be 
a "visual" hint somewhere.

traces.message: Can't find resource for bundle  java.util.PropertyResourceBundle, key icon_path
